author: Abdul Latheef Naha
text:
A video shoot of twin students at GMLP School, Cherumukku, held on Monday with the sanction of the gram panchayat.

The Nannambra gram panchayat, which looks after Kodinhi and Cherumukku, the two little villages that have grabbed international attention because of hundreds of twins being born there, has decided to restrict visitors and media persons who turn up there to photograph and videograph the twins. The panchayat has banned all photo shoots and media coverage of the twins and their families without its consent.

Panchayat president M.P. Mohammed Hasan says the decision was also taken to prevent the “exploitation” of those turning up to shoot the twins and their families. There have been many instances of curious visitors, including foreigners and journalists, being fleeced by local touts who arrange for meeting the twins.

“There have been too many cases of blatant exploitation in the name of the twins. We want to bring in some order and accountability to people coming to shoot and talk to the twins,” Mr. Hasan said.

The panchayat authorities said they would take up the matter of twins more seriously soon.

“We want this phenomenon to be scientifically studied. We will take up this issue after March,” Mr. Hasan said.

The panchayat restriction on visitors has generally been welcomed by the local people.

A.K. Mustafa, a social worker at Cherumukku, said it would actually help people visiting the village to look up the rare phenomenon.

548 pairs, and counting

In Kodinhi alone, there are 548 pairs of twins, according to the figures provided by the panchayat.

The panchayat has banned all photo shoots and media coverage without its consent
title: Kerala’s village of twins to restrict visitors, photographers
